senses.definition: an exam that you have passed or a course of study that you have successfully completed

examples.x: academic/educational/professional/vocational qualifications
a coaching/teaching/nursing qualification
He left school with no formal qualifications.
to have qualifications
to gain/get/obtain/possess/achieve qualifications
In this job, experience counts for more than paper qualifications.
Too many school-leavers lack basic qualifications in English and Maths.

senses.definition: a skill or type of experience that you need for a particular job or activity

examples.x: What qualifications do radio presenters require?
Previous teaching experience is a necessary qualification for this job.

senses.definition: information that you add to a statement to limit the effect that it has or the way it is applied

examples.x: I accept his theories, but not without certain qualifications.
The plan was approved without qualification.

senses.definition: the fact of passing an exam, completing a course of training or reaching the standard necessary to do a job or take part in a competition

examples.x: Nurses in training should be given a guarantee of employment following qualification.
A victory in this game will earn them qualification for the World Cup.

senses.definition: having passed the exams or completed the training that are necessary in order to do a particular job; having the experience to do a particular job

examples.x: a qualified teacher
a qualified instructor/accountant/nurse/doctor
qualified staff/personnel
to be highly qualified
to be suitably/fully qualified
She's extremely well qualified for the job.
I'm not qualified to teach in state schools.

senses.definition: having the practical knowledge or skills to do something

examples.x: I don't know much about it, so I don't feel qualified to comment.
I'm not technically qualified to say anything.
His supporters say he is uniquely qualified to lead the country out of the crisis.

senses.definition: limited in some way

examples.x: The plan was given only qualified support.
The project was only a qualified success.
It was met with qualified enthusiasm.
The proposals received heavily qualified approval.

senses.definition: to reach the standard of ability or knowledge needed to do a particular job, for example by completing a course of study or passing exams

examples.x: How long does it take to qualify?
He qualified as a doctor last year.
She spent seven years qualifying in law.

senses.definition: to give somebody the skills and knowledge they need to do something

examples.x: This training course will qualify you for a better job.
The test qualifies you to drive heavy vehicles.

senses.definition: to be of a high enough standard to enter a competition; to defeat another person or team in order to enter or continue in a competition

examples.x: He failed to qualify.
South Korea qualified for the finals when they beat Italy 6–1.
They qualified for the World Cup.

senses.definition: to have or give somebody the right to do something

examples.x: To qualify, you must have lived in this country for at least three years.
If you live in the area, you qualify for a parking permit.
In order to qualify for scholarships, students must demonstrate potential for academic excellence.
Your educational background, interests and family history are some of the things that might qualify you.
Paying a fee doesn't automatically qualify you for membership.

senses.definition: to have the right qualities to be described as a particular thing

examples.x: Do you think this dress qualifies as evening wear?
It's an old building, but that doesn't qualify it as an ancient monument!

senses.definition: to add something to a previous statement to make the meaning less strong or less general

examples.x: I want to qualify what I said earlier—I didn't mean he couldn't do the job, only that he would need supervision.

senses.definition: to describe another word in a particular way

examples.x: In ‘the open door’, ‘open’ is an adjective qualifying ‘door’.

senses.definition: the standard of something when it is compared to other things like it; how good or bad something is

examples.x: Improving the quality of care for nursing home residents is a priority.
When costs are cut product quality suffers.
The soil here is of poor quality.
The food is fresh and of good quality.
His goal was of top quality.
goods of a high quality
high-quality goods
a decline in water quality
We have seen a marked improvement in the quality of service provided.

senses.definition: a high standard

examples.x: We aim to provide quality at reasonable prices.
They need to decrease costs while maintaining quality.
contemporary writers of quality
Get it right, even if it takes time; it's quality not quantity that matters.

senses.definition: a thing that is part of a person’s character, especially something good

examples.x: personal qualities such as honesty and generosity
to have leadership qualities
She has all the qualities of a good teacher.
It's hard to find people with the right qualities for the job.
He has a lot of good qualities.

senses.definition: a feature of somebody/something, especially one that makes them different from somebody/something else

examples.x: the special quality of light and shade in her paintings
His voice has a rich, melodic quality.

senses.definition: a newspaper that deals seriously with issues and has a high standard of editing and comment
an amount or a number of something

examples.x: a large/small quantity of something
vast/huge quantities of food
enormous/massive/considerable/substantial quantities of something
a product that is cheap to produce in large quantities
Lamb is consumed in large quantities in rural areas.
Is it available in sufficient quantity?

senses.definition: the measurement of something by saying how much of it there is

examples.x: The data is limited in terms of both quality and quantity.

senses.definition: a large amount or number of something

examples.x: The police found a quantity of stolen cash at his home.
I was overwhelmed by the sheer quantity of information available.
She felt daunted by the quantity of books she was expected to read for the course.
Their latest album isn't selling in anything like the quantities that their first one did.
A quantity of jewellery was taken during the burglary.
It's cheaper to buy goods in quantity.

senses.definition: a person or thing whose qualities or abilities are not yet known
one of four equal parts of something

examples.x: a quarter of an hour/a century
a quarter of a mile/million
Almost a quarter of respondents reported employment discrimination.
three quarters of all potential customers
The programme lasted an hour and a quarter.
Cut the apple into quarters.
The theatre was about three quarters full.
He completed his last work a quarter century ago.

senses.definition: a period of 15 minutes either before or after every hour

examples.x: It’s (a) quarter to four now—I’ll meet you at (a) quarter past.
It's quarter of four now—I'll meet you at quarter after.

senses.definition: a period of three months, used especially as a period for which bills are paid or a company’s income is calculated

examples.x: The rent is due at the end of each quarter.
Our gas bill for the last quarter was much higher than usual.
Sales were down 10% in the first quarter of 2024.

senses.definition: a district or part of a town

examples.x: the historic quarter of the city
As a student in Paris, she loved the Latin quarter.
The robbery took place in a normally quiet quarter of the town.

senses.definition: a person or group of people, especially as a source of help, information or a reaction

examples.x: Support for the plan came from an unexpected quarter.
The news was greeted with dismay in some quarters.
The move was met with complaints from all quarters (= from everyone).

senses.definition: a coin of the US and Canada worth 25 cents
rooms that are provided for soldiers, servants, etc. to live in

examples.x: We were moved to more comfortable living quarters.
the servants'/officers' quarters

senses.definition: the period of time twice a month when we can see a quarter of the moon

examples.x: The moon is in its first quarter.

senses.definition: one of the four periods of time into which a game of American football is divided

examples.x: Ford scored the winning touchdown early in the fourth quarter.

senses.definition: a unit for measuring weight, a quarter of a pound; 4 ounces
a unit for measuring weight, 28 pounds in the UK or 25 pounds in the US; a quarter of a hundredweight
kind treatment of an enemy or opponent who is in your power

examples.x: His rivals knew that they could expect no quarter from such a ruthless adversary.

senses.definition: very near

examples.x: fighting at close quarters

senses.definition: the female ruler of an independent state that has a royal family

examples.x: She was crowned queen at the age of fifteen.
kings and queens
the Queen of Norway
Queen Victoria

senses.definition: the wife of a king

examples.x: Henry VII and his queen, Elizabeth of York
The King and Queen of Denmark attended the wedding.

senses.definition: a woman, place or thing that is thought to be one of the best in a particular group or area

examples.x: the queen of fashion
a movie queen
Venice, queen of the Adriatic

senses.definition: a woman or girl chosen to perform official duties at a festival or celebration

examples.x: a carnival queen
a May queen (= at a festival to celebrate the coming of spring)
a homecoming queen
She was nominated for prom queen in high school.

senses.definition: the most powerful piece used in the game of chess that can move any number of squares in any direction
a playing card with the picture of a queen on it
a large female insect that lays eggs for the whole group

examples.x: The bees swarmed around their queen.

senses.definition: an offensive word for a gay man who behaves like a woman
the person considered to be the best, most famous or successful in a particular place or area of activity
a question, especially one asking for information or expressing a doubt about something

examples.x: Our assistants will be happy to answer your queries.
If you have a query about your insurance policy, contact our helpline.

senses.definition: a question mark to show that something has not been finished or decided

examples.x: Put a query against Jack's name—I'm not sure if he's coming.

senses.definition: a long search for something, especially for some quality such as happiness

examples.x: the quest for happiness/knowledge/truth
He set off in quest of adventure.
a quest narrative/novel/story

senses.definition: a sentence, phrase or word that asks for information

examples.x: You didn't answer my question.
You will have the opportunity to ask questions.
Does anyone have any questions?
I would now like to pose two questions:…
That's a very interesting question.
The question is, how much are they going to pay you?
The big question is, why did they do it?
The question arises as to whether or not he knew of the situation.
The key question of what caused the leak remains unanswered.
Can I ask you a question about your first novel?
He put a question to the minister about the recent reforms.
I hope the police don't ask any awkward questions.
This is a difficult question to answer.
The short answer to your question is yes.
The government doesn’t have the answers to these difficult questions.
In an interview try to ask open questions that don't just need ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ as an answer.
I paid cash, no questions asked.

senses.definition: a task or request for information that is intended to test your knowledge or understanding, for example in an exam or a competition

examples.x: Question 3 was very difficult.
I couldn't do Question 6.
You must answer all ten questions.
In the exam there's sure to be a question on energy.

senses.definition: a matter or topic that needs to be discussed or dealt with

examples.x: This is an issue that raises many important questions.
Let's look at the question of security.
Finally we shall deal with the question of cost.
The question that needs to be addressed is one of funding.
Questions remain about how she was appointed.
The case raises serious questions about the company's conduct.
Which route is better remains an open question (= it is not decided).
The film doesn't answer all the questions it raises.
The research is asking the wrong questions.
The new play poses some challenging questions.

senses.definition: doubt or not being certain about something

examples.x: His suitability for the job is open to question.
Her honesty is beyond question.
Her version of events was accepted without question.
This case brings into question the whole purpose of the law.
The authenticity of the painting has been thrown into question.
The safety of the system has recently come into question.
His ability has never been called into question.
I did have some questions as to his motive in coming.
She's a great dancer—there's no question about that.

senses.definition: to make somebody want to ask a question that has not yet been answered

examples.x: All of which begs the question as to who will fund the project.

senses.definition: to talk about something as if it were definitely true, even though it might not be

examples.x: These assumptions beg the question that children learn languages more easily than adults.

senses.definition: used to show that you do not know the answer to a question

examples.x: ‘How much is all this going to cost?’ ‘Good question!’

senses.definition: that is being discussed

examples.x: On the day in question we were in Cardiff.

senses.definition: in doubt; uncertain

examples.x: The future of public transport is not in question.
His sincerity is not in question.

senses.definition: used to say that something is not difficult to predict, explain, do, etc.

examples.x: It's merely a question of time before the business collapses.
It's just a question of deciding what you really want.
Now it's just a question of getting the wording right.

senses.definition: a matter about which there may be difference of opinion or a lack of understanding

examples.x: Whether this should be enforced by law or not is a moot point.

senses.definition: a matter about which there may be difference of opinion or a lack of understanding

examples.x: Whether this should be enforced by law or not is a moot question.

senses.definition: impossible or not allowed and therefore not worth discussing

examples.x: Another trip abroad this year is out of the question.

senses.definition: to ask somebody to marry you
there is/was no possibility of something

examples.x: There was no question of his/him cancelling the trip so near the departure date.

senses.definition: to ask somebody questions about something, especially officially

examples.x: Police are keen to question any witnesses.
Two men are being questioned by police.
Over half of those questioned said they rarely took any exercise.
She was arrested and questioned about the fire.
The students were questioned on the books they had been studying.
‘What's wrong?’ she questioned.

senses.definition: to have or express doubts about something

examples.x: I just accepted what he told me. I never thought to question it.
No one has ever questioned her judgement.
At times I question the wisdom of that decision.
I seriously question his ability to do his job.
He questioned whether the accident was solely the lorry driver's fault.

senses.definition: a written list of questions that are answered by a number of people so that information can be collected from the answers

examples.x: to fill in a questionnaire
to fill out a questionnaire
Local companies were asked to complete a questionnaire about their exports.

senses.definition: a line of people, cars, etc. waiting for something or to do something

examples.x: There were long queues at polling stations.
the bus queue
the front/head/back/end of the queue
I had to join a queue for the toilets.
Patients face lengthy queues for treatment.
There was a queue of traffic waiting to turn right.
There's a queue of people trying to get in.
How long were you in the queue?
Shoppers had to wait in long queues.
I have to stand in a queue at immigration.
I took my place in the queue.

senses.definition: a list of items of data stored in a particular order
to go to the front of a line of people without waiting for your turn
to wait in a line of people, vehicles, etc. in order to do something, get something or go somewhere

examples.x: People queued up outside.
Hundreds of voters queued patiently.
Queue here for taxis.
We had to queue up for an hour for the tickets.
You have to queue to get in at weekends.

senses.definition: to add tasks to other tasks so that they are ready to be done in order; to come together to be done in order

examples.x: The system queues the jobs before they are processed.

senses.definition: done with speed; taking or lasting a short time

examples.x: a quick look/check/search
She gave him a quick glance.
Let's take a quick break.
There's no quick fix for this problem.
Just a quick note to say thanks for lunch yesterday.
Let me just ask one quick question.
Thanks for the quick response.
These cakes are very quick and easy to make.
Do you want to grab a quick coffee?
It's quicker by train.
Are you sure this is the quickest way?
Have you finished already? That was quick!
His quick thinking saved her life.
He fired three shots in quick succession.

senses.definition: moving or doing something fast

examples.x: a quick learner
The kids were quick to learn.
She was quick (= too quick) to point out the mistakes I'd made.
Don't be too quick to dismiss science fiction.
Don't be so quick to judge unless you know all the facts.
Her quick hands suddenly stopped moving.
Try to be quick! We're late already.
Once again, his quick wits (= ability to think quickly) got him out of an awkward situation.
He's a quick study (= he learns quickly).

senses.definition: happening very soon or without delay

examples.x: We need to make a quick decision.
The company wants quick results.
The doctor said she'd make a quick recovery.

senses.definition: to be quick to understand or react in a new situation

examples.x: You can't fool him—he's always quick on the draw.

senses.definition: to be quick at pulling out a gun in order to shoot it
to be quick/slow to understand something

examples.x: Is he always this slow on the uptake?

senses.definition: to become angry easily
to earn money quickly and easily

examples.x: This is a long-term project. We are not out to make a quick buck.

senses.definition: used to describe something that is usually complicated, but is being done quickly and simply in this case

examples.x: Read our quick-and-dirty guide to creating a website.

senses.definition: fast/slow in reacting to a situation

examples.x: If you’re quick off the mark in answering these questions, you could win a prize.
The government was slow off the mark in responding to the crisis.

senses.definition: fast

examples.x: She walked quickly away.
The disease spreads quickly.
The last few weeks have gone quickly (= the time seems to have passed quickly).
The tool makes it possible to create websites quickly and easily.
He worked quickly and efficiently.

senses.definition: soon; after a short time

examples.x: to act/respond quickly
The authorities moved quickly to quell the violence.
'Hey, I was just kidding,' he said quickly.
He replied to my letter very quickly.
It quickly became clear that she was dying.
We'll repair it as quickly as possible.
I quickly realized that this was a big mistake.
We all quickly learned that success comes only with hard work.
He quickly found work as a shop assistant.
Things quickly turned ugly.
He scored a stunning goal, quickly followed by another.
She quickly established a reputation as a painter.
When they saw how much money they could save, they quickly changed their minds

senses.definition: making very little noise

examples.x: her quiet voice
a quieter, more efficient engine
Could you keep the kids quiet while I'm on the phone?
He went very quiet (= did not say much) so I knew he was upset.
‘Be quiet,’ said the teacher.
She crept downstairs (as) quiet as a mouse.
We were all quiet for a moment.

senses.definition: without many people or much noise or activity

examples.x: a quiet street/town
It is a quiet place with just a handful of shops, bars and restaurants.
They lead a quiet life.
After a month of political tensions, things are relatively quiet.
Business is usually quieter at this time of year.
They had a quiet wedding.
The hotel is in a quiet location near the sea.
The negotiations were quiet and hurried.

senses.definition: peaceful; without being interrupted

examples.x: to have a quiet coffee
They were enjoying a quiet moment by the lake.
I was looking forward to a quiet evening at home.

senses.definition: tending not to talk very much

examples.x: She was quiet and shy.

senses.definition: definite but not expressed in an obvious way

examples.x: He had an air of quiet authority.

senses.definition: to say nothing about something; to keep something secret

examples.x: I've decided to resign but I'd rather you kept quiet about it.
This story is too big to be kept quiet.
We'll have to keep this quiet—if it gets out, we'll all be in a lot of trouble.

senses.definition: in a way that makes very little noise

examples.x: to ask/speak/talk quietly
to move/stand quietly
a quietly spoken woman
‘I'm sorry,’ he said quietly.

senses.definition: in a peaceful way; without being interrupted

examples.x: I spent a few hours quietly relaxing.
He noticed the woman sitting quietly at the bar.

senses.definition: without many people or much noise or activity

examples.x: Sometimes a business begins quietly, as a hobby maybe, in a spare bedroom.

senses.definition: in a definite, but not obvious, way

examples.x: He is quietly confident that they can succeed (= he is confident, but he is not talking about it too much).

senses.definition: to leave your job, school, etc.

examples.x: If I don't get more money I'll quit.
He quit in protest over the decision.
He has decided to quit as manager of the team.
to quit your job
He quit the show last year because of bad health.
She quit school at 16.
I am considering quitting my job to start a business.

senses.definition: to stop doing something

examples.x: I've quit teaching.
You don't know me, so quit trying to act like you do.
She finally quit working at age 76.
Just quit it!
We only just started. We're not going to quit now.

senses.definition: to leave the place where you live

examples.x: We decided it was time to quit the city.
The landlord gave them all notice to quit.
I decide to quit town and lie low for a while.

senses.definition: to close a computer program or application

examples.x: I quit the app and restarted it.

senses.definition: to some degree

examples.x: quite good/interesting/common/difficult
I quite like opera.
I quite enjoyed the film to be honest.
He plays quite well.
He's quite a good player.
We had to wait quite a long time.

senses.definition: to the greatest possible degree

examples.x: quite amazing/delicious/empty/perfect
The two species are in fact quite different from one another.
He made it quite clear that he never wanted to see her again.
Quite frankly, I don't blame you.
I've had quite enough of your tantrums.
Are you quite sure?
I quite agree.
Quite apart from all the work, he had financial problems.
Unfortunately it is not quite as simple as that.
I don't quite know what to do next.
I'm sorry, I don't quite understand.
The theatre was not quite (= was almost) full.
It's like being in the Alps, but not quite.
I've never quite understood why she's so successful.
‘I almost think she prefers animals to people.’ ‘Quite right too,’ said Bill.
I'm sorry to be so difficult.’ ‘That's quite all right.’

senses.definition: to a great degree; very; really

examples.x: I'm quite happy to wait for you here.
You'll be quite comfortable here.
I can see it quite clearly.
‘You've no intention of coming back?’ ‘I'm quite sorry, but no, I have not.’

senses.definition: used to agree with somebody or show that you understand them

examples.x: ‘He's bound to feel shaken after his accident.’ ‘Quite.’
‘It’s not something we want to have talked about.’ ‘Quite so.’

senses.definition: used to show that a person or thing is particularly impressive or unusual in some way

examples.x: This is quite a different problem.
She's quite a beauty.
We found it quite a change when we moved to London.
He's quite the little gentleman, isn't he?
It must be quite some car.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that the opposite of what has been said is true

examples.x: I don't find him funny at all. Quite the contrary.

senses.definition: a fairly large number

examples.x: I've been there quite a few times.

senses.definition: a large number or amount of something

examples.x: They drank quite a lot of wine.
There's quite a lot of work still to do.

senses.definition: a large amount of something

examples.x: She hasn't been seen for quite some time.

senses.definition: used to show that a person or thing is particularly impressive or unusual in some way
a limited number or amount of people or things that is officially allowed

examples.x: to introduce a strict import quota on grain

senses.definition: an amount of something that somebody expects or needs to have or achieve

examples.x: I'm going home now—I've done my quota of work for the day.
to get your full quota of sleep

senses.definition: a fixed number of votes that a candidate needs in order to be elected

examples.x: He was 76 votes short of the quota.

senses.definition: a group of words or a short piece of writing taken from a book, play, speech, etc. and repeated because it is interesting or useful

examples.x: a dictionary of quotations
Two short quotations will illustrate my point.
The book began with a quotation from Goethe.
a direct quotation from a recent speech by the president

senses.definition: the act of repeating something interesting or useful that another person has written or said

examples.x: The writer illustrates his point by quotation from a number of sources.

senses.definition: a statement of how much money a particular piece of work will cost

examples.x: You need to get a written quotation before they start work.
We’ll give you a free quotation for replacing your windows.

senses.definition: a statement of the current value of goods or shares

examples.x: the latest quotations from the Stock Exchange
It was the first football club to have a full stock market quotation.

senses.definition: a group of words or a short piece of writing taken from a book, play, speech, etc. and repeated because it is interesting or useful

examples.x: The essay was full of quotes.
a quote from a New York Times article
The text begins with a quote from Oscar Wilde.

senses.definition: a statement of how much money a particular piece of work will cost

examples.x: Their quote for the job was way too high.

senses.definition: a pair of marks (‘  ’) or ( “ ” ) placed around a word, sentence, etc. to show that it is what somebody said or wrote, that it is a title or that you are using it in an unusual way

examples.x: If you take text from other sources, place it in quotes.

senses.definition: to repeat the exact words that another person has said or written

examples.x: to quote Shakespeare
He quoted a passage from the minister's speech.
They quoted from the Bible.
Quote this reference number in all correspondence.
He was widely quoted in the American media.
The figures quoted in this article refer only to Britain.
Jude is one of three people quoted in the story.
to quote an expert/an official/a source
The minister claimed he had been selectively quoted.
The President was quoted in the press as saying that he disagreed with the decision.
She said, and I quote, ‘Life is meaningless without love.’
‘It will all be gone tomorrow.’ ‘Can I quote you on that?’
Don't quote me on this (= this is not an official statement), but I think he is going to resign.
‘The man who is tired of London is tired of life,’ he quoted.

senses.definition: to mention an example of something to support what you are saying

examples.x: Can you quote me an instance of when this happened?
an example that is often quoted as evidence of mismanagement

senses.definition: to tell a customer how much money you will charge them for a job, service or product

examples.x: The agent is quoting a guide price of €250 000.
The price they quoted for the kitchen was too high.
A garage quoted him £80.
They quoted us £300 for installing a shower unit.

senses.definition: to give a market price for shares, gold or foreign money

examples.x: Yesterday the pound was quoted at $1.8285, unchanged from Monday.

senses.definition: to give the prices for a business company’s shares on a stock exchange

examples.x: Several football clubs are now quoted on the Stock Exchange.
publicly quoted companies

senses.definition: used to show the beginning (and end) of a word, phrase, etc. that has been said or written by somebody else

examples.x: It was quote, ‘the hardest decision of my life’, unquote, and one that he lived to regret.
now that the, quote, unquote, ‘real story’ has begun
